journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part N: Journal of Nanoengineering and Nanosystems

title-group.article-title: Experimental investigation on the study of mechanical and microstructural properties of hybrid composite cement beams reinforced with multi-walled carbon nanotubes and carbon fibres

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Civil Engineering, BV Bhomaraddi College of Engineering and Technology, India
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, BV Bhomaraddi College of Engineering and Technology, India

author-notes.corresp: Nagaraj R Banapurmath, Department of Mechanical Engineering, BV Bhomaraddi College of Engineering and Technology, Hubli, Karnataka 580031, India. Email: nr_banapurmath@rediffmail.com

abstract.p: This paper investigates the behavior of reinforced cement composite beams with multi-walled carbon nanotubes and carbon fibers. The percentage of carbon fibers was fixed at 0.25 wt% of cement, while the percentage of multi-walled carbon nanotubes was fixed at 0.75 wt% of cement. Dispersion of both multi-walled carbon nanotubes and carbon fibers was carried out using the ultrasonic energy method. Composite beams were tested under flexure in order to evaluate their mechanical properties such as flexural strength, toughness and ductility. These results were then compared with the results of plain cement control beams. Microstructural tests like scanning electron microscopy, thermo gravimetric analysis and energy dispersive X-ray analysis were conducted on hybrid nanocomposite material, to study the dispersion of carbon nanotubes and carbon fibers, bonding of carbon nanotubes in C-S-H, temperature effects and the elemental composition. From the study it is concluded that the load-carrying capacity of composite beams under three-point loading is substantially higher than for plain controlled beams.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Plain concrete is a brittle material and failures in many construction materials at the micro-scale are typically the result of tiny microcracks. Advanced technological aspects demand higher performing cement-based materials with improved tensile strength and toughness for use in civil engineering projects. Cementitious materials are typically characterized as quasi brittle materials with low tensile strength and low strain capacity, and hence affect the long-term durability of structures. These days, discrete short fibers are widely used to control cracking in fiber-reinforced concrete (FRC).1 Nanotechnology is one of the most actively researched areas with both novel science and useful applications and has gradually become established over the past two decades.2–4

Nanoscience has a central role to play in producing innovative concrete materials for the 21st century.5 It enables scientists to work at the molecular level, atom by atom, to develop new materials fundamentally with new physical and chemical properties.6 Hydrated cement is porous with a pore size distribution that ranges in size from nanometers to millimeters.7 The dimensional range of solids and pores in a hydrated cement paste has been reported in literature.8,9 Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are the subject of one of the most important areas of research.10 The incorporation of multi-walled CNTs (MWCNTs) in cement increases the amount of stiffness of C-S-H gel resulting in stronger material.11 CNTs were discovered in 1991 by Iijima in Japan.12 CNTs are classified as either single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) or MWCNTs. CNTs are found to possess a Young’s modulus of 1 TPa, a yield stress of 100–300 GPa1 and a tensile strength of 63 GPa.13 The present paper utilizes MWCNTs having diameters of 10–30 nm, densities of 1000–2000 kg/m3 and an aspect ratio of 1000. Both micro- and nano-level reinforcements were provided to study the effect on the overall properties of the composite.14

While the exploration for various applications of nanotechnology to develop innovative construction materials continues,15 it is already clear that the science of the very small is making big changes, with numerous economic benefits for the construction industry.16–18 By using CNTs a new material which exhibits enhanced tensile strength, Young’s modulus and improved early-age strain capacity can be created, as found recorded in the literature.18 However, two problems with the addition of CNTs and carbon fibers to any material are the clumping together of the tubes and fibers, and the lack of cohesion between them and the matrix bulk material. A uniform dispersion must be achieved to obtain the desired results.19 The cost of adding CNT’s to concrete may be prohibitive at the moment, but work is being done to reduce their price and at such time the benefits offered by their addition to cementitious materials may become more acceptable. carbon fibers used in conventional FRC have been found to be ideal reinforcing materials. They have established themselves as a suitable material for retrofitting and strengthening purposes. Recently in the field of FRC there has been much enthusiasm for the development of hybrid fiber systems, where two or more types of fibers are combined. Hybrid fiber systems represent a promising approach for making efficient use of fibers, with the intention of conferring the best performance characteristics of each of the constituent fiber types to the composite material.20 The combination of carbon fibers and CNTs can bring significant changes to the overall properties of the composite.21,22

sec.title: Experimental program
sec.p: The experimental program was conducted in two stages: a structural scale test and a microstructural scale test. These are explained below.

sec.title: Structural scale test
sec.p: Materials: the cement used was ordinary Portland cement (OPC).and the physical tests were conducted as per IS: 8112-198923 and are presented in Table 1. MWCNTs used in this study were of industrial grade with a purity of greater than 95%. The properties of MWCNTs and carbon fibers used in the study are given in Table 2. Experimental tests were conducted to investigate the effect of uniformly dispersed and randomly oriented nano MWCNTs and micro carbon fibers level reinforcement in cement paste beams. Three-point bending tests were carried out on 20 mm × 20 mm × 100 mm beams with water–cement ratio (w/c) of 0.35 in order to compare the flexural response of control beams and CNT/cement beams.1 A w/c ratio of 0.35 was found to be appropriate in terms of mixing and workability of the paste after adding the fibers. Test specimens used were designated accordingly as: plain cement (PC), plain cement + carbon fiber (PC1) and A3; their details are given in Table 3. For each test six specimens were considered and the average results only are presented in the results and discussion section. The equipment used for the three-point bending test is given in Table 4.

caption.p: Test results of ordinary Portland cement (OPC).
Properties of MWCNTs and carbon fibers used for the study.

tr.th: MWCNTs (as supplied by Intelligent Private Ltd)

tr.td: Carbon fibers (as supplied by Fosroc-Chemicals, Bangalore)

tr.th: Percentage of carbon fiber (5 mm long)

tr.td: To study dispersion and bonding effect of MWCNTs in C-S-H gel
Temperature range: ambient temperature to 1400°C; records temperature every 3 s
To study the loss of weight of sample under high temperature
Electron gun used: tungsten filament along with SEM
To study the elemental composition of the sample

sec.p: Uniform dispersion of MWCNTs against their agglomeration due to van der Waals’ bonding is the first step in the processing of nanocomposites.24 Dispersion is a critical issue while mixing CNTs in either water or organic solvents. Ethanol was used for the pre-dispersion of MWCNTs using the sonication method.10 Care was taken to ensure evaporation of ethanol, and later water was added without taking into account the amount of ethanol used in the w/c ratio of the cement paste. MWCNTs in the quantity 0.75% by weight of cement were added and the whole mixture was kept in an ultrasonicator for 90 min to achieve satisfactory dispersion. The same dispersion method was repeated for all the proportions of MWCNTs.

Similarly, short carbon fibers 5 mm long were placed in a glass beaker. These fibers were pre-dispersed in water by adding three-fifths of the total water, which was used for the preparation of samples to ensure that they were immersed completely in water. The beaker was vibrated by ultrasonic wave.24 Sonication was carried out for 10 min. After that, dispersant hydroxyethyl cellulose (HEC) in the quantity 0.6% by weight of cement was added to the pre-dispersed mixture and again sonicated for another 10 min with continuous stirring. The addition of HEC converts the fibers into a sticky paste and thus bundled carbon fibers become dispersed. Separately, sonicated MWCNTs and carbon fibers were mixed with cement with the addition of the remaining water for a thorough mixing, and sonicated again for another 30 min. After this process, the paste was carefully placed into prepared moulds and compacted using a tamping rod. The cast specimens were demolded after 24 h and cured for up to 28 days. Finally, the composite beams were tested on day 28. To serve as the control, plain cement beams without any fiber reinforcement and beams of plain cement with 0.25 wt% cement of carbon fiber reinforcement were cast, demolded and cured with the composite specimens for the same amount of time.25–28 In addition, the toughness of the composite was determined by measuring the area under the load–deflection curves. The ductility of the composite was also determined using the load–deflection responses.

sec.title: Microstructural scale test
sec.p: Investigations with respect to microstructure were carried out to find the effectiveness of the fibers at the nanoscale; their distribution, efficiency in terms of load-carrying capacity and arresting crack propagation in the composite material were considered. Details of the equipment used for conducting the microstructural scale testing are given in Table 4.

list-item.p: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) test: microscopic investigations were carried out using SEM to visualize the change in the microstructure. The morphology and the microstructure of the fracture surface of CNT nanocomposites were investigated using an ultra-high resolution field emission SEM. Specimens were tested after 28 days of curing. Prior to their observation, the fracture surface of the specimens were sputter-coated with a 20 nm thick layer of gold–palladium (Au/Pd).

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) test: the phase composition of the composite was characterized by means of TGA. The samples were roughly crushed from the binder, which was finely ground. The powder obtained by grinding the binder was finally sieved using a sieve with aperture of 40 μm. Thermal oxidation of CNTs was investigated by means of TGA. About 10 mg of the samples were placed in an alumina sample pan and the TGA experiments were performed.

X-ray diffractometer (EDX) test: the mineralogy was analyzed by means of EDX analysis. The focus here was to find if any changes in chemical composition had taken place in the matrix after the reinforcement with MWCNTs. EDX was carried out on the A3 sample (this is shown later in Fig. 5).

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The results and discussion are covered under the two headings of structural scale and microstructural scale tests, as explained below.

sec.title: Structural scale test
sec.p: Figure 1(a) shows the load versus mid-span deflection curves and compares the behavior of the plain cement beam and plain cement with carbon fibers (0.25 wt% of cement) reinforced beams together with MWCNTs 0.75 wt% of cement and carbon fibers 0.25 wt% of cement reinforced beams. Fig. 1(b) shows the load versus deflection curve for A3 samples only in detail. For this, six sample readings have been taken, A31 to A36.

caption.p: (a) Load–deflection curves for all proportions for three-point loading set-up. (b) Load–deflection curves for only A3 samples.
PC: plain cement; CF: carbon fiber; MWCNT: multi-walled carbon nanotube.

sec.p: Figure 2 shows the placement of samples under three-point loading. The material behavior was found to be more plastic and there was no perfect yield point, as observed from the load–deflection plot. Initially the material undergoes a higher amount of deformation even at lesser loads. With the addition of MWCNTs, the composite beams show greater amount of load-carrying capacity and increased deflections. This is due to the reinforcing effect provided by the fibers and nanotubes. They will absorb a greater amount of energy by inhibiting the microcracks and thereby the energy needed to propagate the cracks will be greater. Table 5 shows a representation of the variation of the ultimate load for different proportions of MWCNTs.

caption.p: Test results for MWCNT + carbon fiber reinforced cement composite under three-point loading for beams.

sec.p: From Tables 5 and 6, a remarkable increase in both flexural strength and toughness value can be observed and this is due to the reinforcing effect of MWCNTs and carbon fibers. The addition of 0.25 wt% of carbon fibers to the cement paste enhances the load-carrying capacity by about 150%. Further, by adding 0.25 wt% of carbon fiber and 0.75 wt% of MWCNT, the load-bearing capacity increases by about 366.67%. This indicates that the presence of both micro and nano level fibers enhances the load-carrying capacity significantly. Moreover the toughness represented by the area under the load–deflection curve of the composite beams has increased significantly with the addition of micro- and nano-sized fibers. The ductility index, as shown in Table 7, for A3 is found to be 1.067 in comparison with PC and PC1.

caption.p: Comparison of overall behavior of the composites under three-point loading.
Ductility index of the composites under three-point loading for composite beams.

tr.th: Load corresponding to 85% of peak load, P85 (N)
Deflection corresponding to 85% of peak load, δ85 (mm)

sec.title: SEM
sec.p: Figure 3 shows SEM images of the cement matrix reinforced with MWCNTs. It can be noted that the microfiber can be observed clearly, with most of the upper part of the microfiber being covered with cement paste hydration products, which indicates good bonding between the fiber and the matrix. A close view of the carbon microfibers and the cement matrix reinforced with MWCNTs is seen. As seen in Fig. 4, the MWCNTs appear to be homogeneously distributed in the matrix, bridging nanocracks and pores. Both images show that the MWCNTs are effectively reinforcing the matrix at the nanoscale level, while carbon microfibers, owing to their larger diameter, can efficiently bridge the larger-scale pores and cracks.

caption.p: SEM micrographs showing microstructure of sample MWCNTs.
SEM micrographs showing microstructure of sample with MWCNTS bridging nanocracks and pores.

sec.title: TGA test
sec.p: The summary of the TGA test on hybrid nanocomposite material is given in Table 8. From the TGA analysis it is observed that the samples undergo decomposition in three stages. In the first stage decomposition occurred between ambient temperature and 200 °C. Here we find that the weight loss follows an exponential curve corresponding to dehydration of cement materials. We also find that from ambient temperature to 200 °C the sample loses around 12.59% of its weight. The second stage occurs between 200 °C and 700 °C. Here we find that the weight loss follows a linear curve, which was attributed to major weight loss due to decomposition of incorporated of MWCNT’s. Here there is a loss of around 13% over the temperature range of 200–700 °C.

caption.p: Summary of TGA test on hybrid nanocomposite material.

sec.title: EDX test
sec.p: The summary of the EDX analysis of the nanocomposite is presented in the Table 9; as seen from the EDX analysis, we can determine the exact elemental composition at various points in the SEM graph. From Fig. 5 the analyses at the points where MWCNTs are present show around 74.39% of carbon and just 23% of oxygen, thereby providing better strength. EDX investigations proved the presence of significant amount of oxygen bonded on the side walls of MWCNTs.

caption.p: Summary of EDX test on hybrid nanocomposite material.

tr.th: Sample, where EDX point was taken

caption.p: Showing the location of EDX taken.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A novel nano-hybrid cement composite was successfully developed in this work using multi-scale fiber reinforcement. Carbon microfibers were used to reinforce cement paste at the micro scale while MWCNTs were chosen at the nanoscale. Results of three-point bending tests on the notched hybrid specimens have shown that the combinations of MWCNTs and carbon microfiber increases the flexural strength to 242.85% in comparison with PC (the control beam). Furthermore, PC1 showed an increase of 114% in comparison with PC. This indicates that the reinforcement both at nano and micro level have increased the flexural strength. Also it is observed that there is no significant increase in ductility index for PC1 and A3. The toughness for A3 is 230 N mm in comparison with PC, which is 29.1 N mm. Observations by SEM confirmed the homogeneous dispersion of the MWCNTs, the good bonding between the nano-and microfibers and the cement hydration products, and the synergistic effect of MWCNTs and the microfibers in controlling cracking at different scales. From the TGA, we find that we can increase the weight loss of the samples with an increase in MWCNT composition. This is due to the very high thermal conductivity of MWCNTs (2000–3000 W/mK) which thus causes a faster evaporation of water and decomposition of other chemical constituents.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
